On the 7th December, 1941, the United States
was shaken to its core, when the Japanese

32.text:
launched a surprise military strike on their
naval base, at Pearl Harbor.

36.text:
The attack destroyed almost 200 U.S aircraft
and killed 2,400 Americans. 24 hours after

43.text:
the attack, congress reversed its political
position of neutrality in the conflict raging

48.text:
across the rest of the world. It declared
war on the Empire of Japan, inevitably leading

60.text:
to war with Japan’s allies, Germany and
Italy. The events at Pearl Harbor 
became an important fixture in American war

85.text:
But the questions surrounding how Japan managed
to launch a secret attack on an American naval

89.text:
base persisted. In 1944 journalist John T.
Flynn argued that, shockingly, President Franklin

96.text:
Delaney Roosevelt had prior knowledge of the
attack but let it happen, in order to justify

101.text: America entering the Second World War.

105.text:
In 2001 former sailor Robert Stinnett claimed
to have uncovered evidence that the Roosevelt

113.text:
administration deliberately provoked and allowed
the Japanese to attack Pearl Harbor, in order

118.text: to bring the USA into the world war.

129.text:
Stinnett argues that America had broken Japan’s
secret naval code as early as 1940 and was

135.text:
able to intercept Japanese transmissions.
But Stinnett’s claim is dismissed by historians

143.text:
who have shown that Japan’s messages couldn’t
be decrypted by the time of the attack.

149.text:
Even if the US hadn’t managed to learn about
Japan’s imminent attack by deciphering coded

153.text:
messages, Stinnett also claims that radio
signals from the approaching Japanese fleet

158.text:
as they crossed the Pacific Ocean would have
been detected early on by US intelligence.

163.text:
He says this information was deliberately
not passed on to the Naval officers stationed

168.text:
But this theory has also been discredited.
Surviving officers from the Japanese strike

173.text:
force have testified that all of the radio
transmitters aboard their ships and airplanes

177.text:
were disabled, to ensure that the fleet remained
radio silent.

181.text:
Stinnett also argues that America moved their
naval base to the Pacific ocean in order to

187.text:
lure the Japanese into attacking it. Historian
Mark Parillo, in his essay ‘The United States

190.text:
in the Pacific’, emphasizes the strategic
importance of Pearl Harbor being located in

194.text:
the Pacific. As Japan was set on a course
of conquering territories in the Pacific,

200.text:
Roosevelt “would have been foolish to sacrifice
one of the major instruments needed to win

204.text:
the war just to get the United States into
it.”

207.text:
Whilst most scholars, including CIA historian
Donald Steury, dismiss Stinnett’s claims

213.text:
as baseless, there does appear to be evidence
that the USA’s increasingly harsh sanctions

219.text:
against Japan strained their relationship
to the point of inevitable conflict between

225.text:
Diary entries by the United States Secretary
of War, Henry L. Stimson, detail a revealing

230.text:
meeting with the President. The diary records
that, just 10 days before the attack, Roosevelt

236.text:
pondered 'how to maneuver the Japanese into
the position of firing the first shot without

241.text:
allowing America to engage themselves.’
In reviewing his diary after the war, Stimson

246.text:
revealed that the commanders at Pearl Harbor
had been warned of the possibility of attack

250.text:
and that he was surprised at how unprepared
the navy base was in case of attack.

256.text:
The theory that Roosevelt had advanced knowledge
of the attack on Pearl Harbor has been rejected

260.text:
by mainstream historians. But an authorized
Congress investigation into how the Japanese

265.text:
managed to ambush Pearl Harbor, known as the
Clausen Inquiry, found that Roosevelt’s

269.text:
government underestimated Japan’s capabilities
and intentions and lacked the adequate intelligence

274.text:
necessary to fully prepare the army and navy
for an attack.

278.text:
However, 75 years later, many of the documents
relating to the Pearl Harbor attack still

284.text:
remain classified, whilst others were destroyed
during the war. With so much obscurity still

290.text:
surrounding the Japanese attack, we may never
know the extent to which FDR had prior 
knowledge of Pearl Harbor.
